description: From Middle English incarnat, incarnate, from Ecclesiastical Latin incarnātus, past participle of incarnārī (“be made flesh”), from in- + Latin carō (“flesh”).

entries.meaning: (traditionally postpositive, now frequently prepositive) Embodied in flesh; given a bodily, especially a human, form; personified.
examples: He  […] represents the emperor and his wife as two devils incarnate, sent into the world for the destruction of mankind.

description: From the past participle stem of Latin incarnāre (“make flesh”), from in- + carō (“flesh”).

verbs.description: incarnate (third-person singular simple present incarnates, present participle incarnating, simple past and past participle incarnated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To embody in flesh, invest with a bodily, especially a human, form.
examples: For one thing, we virtually decided that these morbidities and the hellish Himalayan Mi-Go were one and the same order of incarnated nightmare.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To incarn; to become covered with flesh, to heal over.
examples: My uncle Toby’s wound was near well, and as soon as the surgeon recovered his surprize, and could get leave to say as much—he told him, 'twas just beginning to incarnate.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make carnal; to reduce the spiritual nature of.
(transitive, figurative) To put into or represent in a concrete form, as an idea.
